repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Second Industrial Sector
            Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Second Industrial Sector Adjustment
            Credit (ISAC-II) in Bangladesh. ISAC-II supported a wide
            range of reforms in three areas: (1) Import liberalization
            to reduce and rationalize effective protection and also to
            streamline import procedures; (2) Export Promotion through:
            (i) improved coverage and operation of the duty drawback and
            bonding programs to provide direct and indirect exporters
            with world priced inputs; and (ii) a more strategic approach
            to other aspects of export promotion utilizing a
            strengthened Export Promotion Bureau, matching grants, and
            deregulation. Three main lessons were learned to reduce the
            risk of partial failure in support for complex reform
            programs :( 1) Adequate allowance should be made for the
            ability of an unconvinced and/or technically weak
            bureaucracy to thwart essential institutional aspects of
            policy reform; ( 2) Projects which involve reform in several
            areas at once need commitment from all concerned Ministers,
            with collective responsibility and/or strong leadership.( 3)
            A Comprehensive reform agenda should be supported by several
            operations and non-lending instruments, either in series or parallel.

repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Second Industrial Sector
            Adjustment Credit

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Industrial Sector Adjustment
            Credit Project will support the implementation of a program
            of reforms designed to promote export-oriented private
            sector-led development of the industrial sector. They
            include import liberalization, strengthening of institutions
            involved with export promotion and reforms aimed at
            transforming the regulatory stance of the Government towards
            private sector development to a promotional one. The reform
            program will: (1) increase Bangladesh's competitiveness
            and potential for labor-intensive growth; (2) increase
            producers' ability to respond quickly to changing
            market conditions while reducing opportunities for
            unproductive rent seeking; and (3) enhance the
            Government's capacity for efficient performance in
            policy making and delivering services to export and other
            private producers. Its comprehensiveness is intended to
            facilitate a good supply response to the trade policy reforms.
